title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that law enforcement officers face increasing challenges in the war against drugs and crime, with a rise in violent crime and drug use. The support from the Federal Government has not kept pace with these evolving problems, and a review is needed to address current issues highlighted by the Presidential Commission on Law Enforcement and the Administration of Justice in 1965. A review twenty-five years later is needed to evaluate current problems in law enforcement, including drug-related crime, violence, racial conflict, and decreased funding. A comprehensive study on law enforcement issues, such as the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers, working conditions, and responsibility for crime control, would help redefine relationships between the Federal Government, the public, and law enforcement officials. A national commission called the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" is established. The Commission's duties include evaluating current problems in law enforcement and studying issues like the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers and responsibility for crime control. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement will study and recommend changes regarding law enforcement agencies and issues at all levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, research and training, equipment and resources, and cooperation among Federal, State, and local agencies. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement will conduct surveys and consult with focus groups to gather information and advice on important law enforcement issues, including equipment, resources, cooperation among agencies, responsibility, and the impact of the criminal justice system. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement consists of 25 members, including individuals from national law enforcement organizations representing officers and management. Appointments are made by various leaders in the government. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement includes 7 individuals from national law enforcement organizations appointed by different government leaders, and 2 individuals with academic expertise appointed by specific government officials. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement includes various individuals appointed by government leaders, such as Members of the House and Senate, individuals from federal law enforcement agencies, and representatives from the Department of Justice and Department of the Treasury. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement includes individuals appointed by government leaders from various entities, such as the Department of the Treasury, Department of Justice, State or local governmental entities, and the President. The Comptroller General serves in an advisory capacity overseeing the Commission's study methodology. The National Commission to Support Law Enforcement includes members appointed by government leaders, with a Comptroller General overseeing the study methodology. Commission members will select a chairperson and receive travel expenses but no additional compensation. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may procure temporary services from experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services as requested. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission, under Section 7, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, delegate actions, obtain information from Federal agencies, accept gifts, and use the United States mails. Additionally, they may procure temporary services from experts, consultants, and detail personnel from Federal agencies. Administrative support services are provided by the Administrator of General Services. The Commission will submit a report with findings and proposals to Congress within eighteen months of its appointment. It will cease to exist sixty days after submitting the report. Two specific titles from previous acts will be repealed.
